awd_titl_txt: The Dynamics of Inhibition in Social Cognitive Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the role of distinct mechanisms for inhibition on children's developing social cognition, specifically focused on their understanding of others' mental states, their trust in others' knowledge, and their understanding of fairness. In addition to enhancing knowledge about how specific mechanisms of inhibition develop, the project will address long-standing debates in social cognition regarding the role of inhibition in development. Isolating the role of different inhibitory processes in children's social judgment specifies the mechanisms through which children develop social cognitive knowledge, and cognitive development more generally. Understanding how these processes unfold also applies to real-world practice. By examining how children understand others' mental states, the researchers will be able to provide a framework for describing how children resolve conflicts with others. By examining how children develop concepts of fairness, the researchers will be able to identify factors contributing to cooperation and moral development. These findings have the potential to impact curriculum design and interventions designed to promote social cognitive development. 
          
This project uses a technique called reach trajectory tracking (RTT), which measures how children engage in reaching behaviors in response to scenes shown to them on a screen. Different mechanisms of inhibitory control are reflected by the speed and trajectory of children's reaching responses. Three lines of research in social cognition will be addressed: children's theory of mind, selective social learning, and prosocial behavior. Each line of research targets the developmental trajectory of a social-cognitive process and discerns the role of distinct inhibitory processes in that development. In this way, the research team can articulate ways in which children's social cognition develops and what role inhibition plays in this development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For many years, researchers have posited that children’s developing inhibitory control plays a role in how their social inferences change. For example, to understand that another person has a false belief about the world, children must inhibit the actual state of the world in favor of a representation of what another might be thinking. Prior to being able to inhibit the actual state of the world, children might struggle with understanding that others’ beliefs can be false. Children might also struggle with recognizing when someone is being deceptive. Recognizing someone is lying involves inhibiting the information that person generates in favor of an alternate piece of information (such as that the opposite of what that person says is true). Finally, inhibitory control is involved in making fair decisions. For instance, to behave fairly when evaluating how resources should be distributed, children must inhibit their desire to gain resources, particularly when others are disadvantaged.

Although there have been many findings suggesting correlation between all of these abilities and children’s performance on measures of inhibitory control, those findings are not causal – they do not reflect the usage of inhibitory mechanisms while children are making inferences. Moreover, these findings treat inhibitory control as a single construct, which does not reflect recent cognitive neuroscience evidence suggesting that inhibitory control is a set of distinct processes working in tandem. Prior to the start of this proposal, the PI and Co-PI developed a paradigm to measure children’s (and adults’) inhibitory control while making inferences. By tracking the dynamics of participants’ hand movements as they respond on a vertical touch screen, they could isolate two distinct processes involved in inhibition. The first concerned a participants’ ability to monitor for and detect conflict between information they observed and a response they had to generate. The second concerned a participants’ ability to resolve the conflict they had detected by changing the nature of their response.

What this grant did was apply what we had learned about using this reach tracking method to study the role of inhibitory control in children’s social inferences. We conducted experiments about children’s developing theory of mind, about children’s interaction with deceptive informants, and about children’s inferences about fairness. These studies found distinct roles of inhibitory control mechanisms in each domain. Moreover, because the majority of the research took place during the COVID pandemic, we pivoted in our data collection to adult participants, who were included in our investigations. This way, we could describe what facets of inhibitory control showed continuity (i.e., did not change between childhood and adulthood) and what facets developed.

For example, consider inferences about fairness. Both children and adults needed more inhibitory resources when they were faced with reasoning about a disadvantageous inequity; when participants had to reason about cases where they received fewer resources than others, they used more inhibitory resources related to detecting conflict. There was no development between 5-8-year-olds and adults. In contrast, when reasoning about advantageous inequities – cases where the participant got more than another - participants didn’t need more inhibitory resources about detecting conflict, but 5- to 8-year-olds needed more inhibitory resources related to conflict resolution in order to decide what to do.   

Each of the studies supported by this grant looked at the role of inhibitory control during these kinds of social decisions. In addition to judgments about fairness, we considered social interactions with deceptive or accurate informants and social interactions where others potentially had false beliefs about the location of objects. Because the COVID pandemic prohibited in person data collection, we also considered metanalyses and other forms of remote data collection in order to gain relevant background and make novel contributions to the study of social cognitive development.

Because we demonstrated that different kinds of social inferences use different processes related to inhibitory control, it is our hope that researchers can apply these findings to interventions that could help social cognitive development. For example, interventions that focus on inhibitory control, such as perspective taking, might have some efficacy in leading children to more fair decisions when it comes to how they think resources might be divided or collected. It is our hope that educators use these findings to inform practice. Further, the paradigm we developed – based on manual reach tracking – is a vibrant way of studying inhibitory control in decision making across various domains, which hopefully inspires other researchers in the future.
